channel.title: Java Bug System
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [JDK-8334600] TEST java/net/MulticastSocket/IPMulticastIF.java fails on linux-aarch64
item.description:
TEST java/net/MulticastSocket/IPMulticastIF.java fails on linux-aarch64

test log snippet:
--- testSetGetInterfaceBound bindAddr=[iZbp16qsgpomcsq1pwzhjiZ/[fe80:0:0:0:216:3eff:fe30:9088]:0], nif=[name:docker0 (docker0)]
test IPMulticastIF.testSetGetInterfaceBound(java.net.InetSocketAddress@7c45b3b8, name:docker0 (docker0)): failure
java.net.SocketException: Invalid argument
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.Net.setInterface6(Native Method)
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.DatagramChannelImpl.setOption(DatagramChannelImpl.java:381)
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.DatagramSocketAdaptor.setOption(DatagramSocketAdaptor.java:379)
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.DatagramSocketAdaptor.setNetworkInterface(DatagramSocketAdaptor.java:564)
at java.base/java.net.MulticastSocket.setNetworkInterface(MulticastSocket.java:444)
at IPMulticastIF.testSetGetInterfaceBound(IPMulticastIF.java:79)

--- testSetGetInterfaceBound bindAddr=[iZbp16qsgpomcsq1pwzhjiZ/[fe80:0:0:0:216:3eff:fe30:9088]:0], nif=[name:veth28fedcd (veth28fedcd)]
test IPMulticastIF.testSetGetInterfaceBound(java.net.InetSocketAddress@a5773c1, name:veth28fedcd (veth28fedcd)): failure
java.net.SocketException: Invalid argument
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.Net.setInterface6(Native Method)
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.DatagramChannelImpl.setOption(DatagramChannelImpl.java:381)
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.DatagramSocketAdaptor.setOption(DatagramSocketAdaptor.java:379)
at java.base/sun.nio.ch.DatagramSocketAdaptor.setNetworkInterface(DatagramSocketAdaptor.java:564)
at java.base/java.net.MulticastSocket.setNetworkInterface(MulticastSocket.java:444)
at IPMulticastIF.testSetGetInterfaceBound(IPMulticastIF.java:79)

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
[jdk21u-fix-request] Approval Request from sendaoYan
Backport JDK-8334600 to fix the testcase bug, make the more robustness. Only change test testcase, no risk.

[jdk17u-fix-request] Approval Request from sendaoYan
Backport JDK-8334600 to fix the testcase bug, make the more robustness. Only change test testcase, no risk.

A pull request was submitted for review.
Branch: master
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk21u-dev/pull/805
Date: 2024-06-28 15:38:35 +0000

A pull request was submitted for review.
Branch: master
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk17u-dev/pull/2646
Date: 2024-06-28 15:38:37 +0000

A pull request was submitted for review.
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/pull/19945
Date: 2024-06-28 15:36:28 +0000

Changeset: f23295ec
Author: Daniel Fuchs <dfuchs@openjdk.org>
Date: 2024-06-26 10:09:05 +0000
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/commit/f23295ec1dde58d239a2625c9b1645534a2bb625

A pull request was submitted for review.
URL: https://git.openjdk.org/jdk/pull/19881
Date: 2024-06-25 13:22:38 +0000

It is strange to set an outbound interface which is different than the interface the socket is bound to, when the socket is not bound to the wildcard. If we do that - then maybe we should accept the exception as a valid result.
Mark's suggestion to filter out docker0 might be the simplest thing to do here.

The recommended usage of MulticastSocket is to bind to the wildcard address as it is very platform specific as to whether a UDP socket bound to a specific address can receive multicast datagrams. There are of course applications that want want to bind to the multicast address but this isn't generally portable.

The test was originally created in the context of the Windows support for IPv6 that used two sockets, that implementation no longer exists. I would expect binding to another address and then setting the output multicast interface to a different network interface will work but I assume will fail when attempting to send a multicast datagram. It feel like it's testing platform specific behavior and I'm kinda surprised it has been passing on all platforms/configurations for many years.

surely docker0 should be excluded from the test, unless the test is being executed within a Docker container
 similar to Teredo on Windows or awdl0 on macOS exclusion in various tests

[~alanb] I don't understand what the test is doing (with the `scenarios` provider)

It binds the socket to an address exported by one interface e.g. `eth0`, and then attempts to set another outgoing interface e.g, `docker0`.
Is that expected to work? I mean - is it expected that setOption will not throw ?

It would be useful to see the network configuration of this container. I assume the issue is that the docker0 interface doesn't have any IPv6 addresses configured, which hints that the "scenarios" data provider may have a bug where it yields a test case for a link-local IPv6 address but a target network interface that does not support IPv6.

Update: Sendao Yan has updated the bug to add this information.
